awd_titl_txt: Active Sequential Change-Point Analysis of Multi-Stream Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop efficient methodologies and algorithms for actively learning from high-dimensional streaming data under the sampling or resource constraints. In many real-world applications, a system consists of many processes that can generate many data streams. At some unknown time, an unusual event could occur to the system, for example, a disease outbreak, a manufacturing defect, or a fraud signal, yielding a set of anomalous processes. Most systems however are operated under resource constraints that prevent the simultaneous use of all resources all the time. Thus, the decision maker must be responsible for actively choosing which processes are prioritized for observation. This will enhance their existing knowledge about the occurring event or anomalous processes while exploring new information and accounting for the penalty of the wrong declaration. The research would have broader impacts in a wide range of real-world applications such as biosurveillance, epidemiology, engineering, homeland security, and finance. The project will integrate research and education by infusing research findings into the curriculum and by training graduate students.

This project seeks to make comprehensive progress on methodology, theory, and application of active sequential change-point analysis of multi-stream data under the sampling or resource constraints.  The specific research aims are: (1) design efficient active change-point detection algorithms with false alarm guarantees, (2) develop an asymptotic theory to characterize statistical performances of the developed methods, (3) post-hoc analysis to apply false discovery rate methods to identify anomalous processes; and (4) applications in sepsis screening with online monitoring data from medical sensors in intensive care units to identify sepsis patients as quickly as possible while avoiding alarm fatigue. Results of the project are expected to significantly advance the state of the art in sequential analysis, change-point detection, multi-armed bandit problems, streaming data analysis, and large-scale inference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed innovative algorithms and useful theory for active sequential change-point analysis under the sampling or resource constraints. From the technical aspects, this project develops algorithms under four different practical settings.

In the first line of work, we developed fundamental asymptotic optimal theories for monitoring multi-stream data with only one affected local stream under the sampling control that one can only observe one local stream. For the fixed dimension or number of local streams, we established a surprising theoretical result that cyclic-myopic sampling-based sequential change-point algorithm is second-order asymptotically optimal when the post-change distribution is completely specified, and is first-order asymptotically optimal when the post-change distributions involve unknown parameters. Our theoretical research suggests that as long as the number of observable local streams is larger than or equal to the (unknown) number of affected local streams, then asymptotic optimality theories are generally hold, at least under the i.i.d. models. This provides the theoretical foundations of active sequential change-point detection.        

In the second line of work, we developed efficient high-dimensional active sequential change-point detection algorithm from the limiting Bayesian viewpoint by combining the Thompson Sampling algorithm from Multi-Armed Bandit Problems (MAB) with the Shiryaev-Roberts procedures from the classical sequential change-point detection. In the high dimension setting, cyclic-myopic sampling-based strategies no longer is efficient, and a main challenge is that we need to balance the tradeoff between exploration and exploitation. Thus we propose to combine sampling strategies from MAB with sequential change-point detection methods in a novel way to develop a statistically efficient and computationally scalable algorithm. This opens new research direction on active sequential change-point detection methods.   

In the third line of work, we develop active sequential change-point detection algorithm by exploring implicit regularization properties of optimization algorithms such as gradient descent algorithm under the over-parametric setting. In the statistical literature, explicit regularization such as LASSO or L1-norm is standard to tackle sparsity in the high-dimension. In recent year, research on deep neural networks suggest that gradient descent algorithm under the over-parametric setting enjoys regularization properties as well. By treating linear regression models as a two-layer neural networks, we show that asymptotically optimal sequential change-point detection algorithms are developed for monitoring the sparse change of high-dimensional linear regression coefficients. This might open new research direction to better combine optimization with streaming data analysis.   

In the fourth line of work, we apply the ideas and techniques from our theoretical and methodology research to tackle several real-world applications, including hot-spot detection in spatial-temporal data that are non-stationary over time, either continuous Gaussian or Poisson count data, privacy of sequential hypothesis testing, active-learning-based muti-stage sequential decision-making model with application on common bible duct stone evaluation, PDE recovery from noisy data via splines or kernel smoothing.   

Overall, the success of this project advances the state of the art in monitoring high-dimensional streaming data under the sampling or resource constraints, and contribute to the science base of biosurveillance and epidemiology, and quality control in engineering. Moreover, graduate students who worked on the project received training in the areas of statistics, data mining, optimization, and biomedical applications. Furthermore, the technical outcomes were published as sixteen (16) journal papers in top journals and seven (7) conference papers in top conferences in the related areas, and also embedded into several graduate course modules.
